author: Natalie O'Neill
title: It’s not easy being a ‘Saddam Hussain’
text:
If you think the job market is rough, trying sending out resumes with the name Saddam Hussain.
An Indian engineer with the unfortunate name is headed to court to get a new one because he’s been turned down for more than 40 jobs, according to a report.
“People are scared to hire me,” said Hussain, of Jamshedpur, whose grandpa graced him with the resume-wrecking handle, according to the Hindustan Times .
Hussain, a 20-something who graduated from the private school Noorul Islam University two years ago, said his classmates have had no trouble landing great careers all over the world.
But after he was rejected from dozens of jobs, he called some of the firms to find out why.
“I inquired with the HR departments of the companies and some of them told me my name was the problem,” he told the paper. “I am an innocent victim of somebody else’s crimes.”
Some of the companies feared his name would become a hassle when traveling for business to countries such as the U.S., he said.
Hussain — who actually spells his surname slightly differently that the dead Iraqi despot — now wants to change his first name to Sajid.
But he’s been wrapped up in bureaucratic red tape for months.
A Jharkhand high court hearing is set for May 5 for the name change.
